content.webTitle: Samantha Armytage dumped from UNHCR lunch with Kristin Davis

fields.headline: Samantha Armytage dumped from UNHCR lunch with Kristin Davis
fields.bodyText: Sunrise presenter Samantha Armytage has been dumped by Australia for UNHCR as host of a lunch with Sex and the City star Kristin Davis after the refugee ambassador was embarrassed on live TV by the Sunrise hosts. Armytage was to be the star host at a $200-a-head lunch at Sydney’s Ivy on Friday at which Davis is speaking about her work with refugees, but organisers have replaced her at the 11th hour. The lunch will be hosted by Australia for UNHCR national director Naomi Steer instead. A spokeswoman for Australia for UNHCR gave no reason for the late change in host. “I can confirm that Sam Armytage will not be hosting the lunch today,” she told Guardian Australia on Friday. “The MC will be Australia for UNHCR national director Naomi Steer.” Davis, who played Charlotte in the long-running TV show, agreed to an exclusive interview on the Seven breakfast show on condition the program would focus on her work with the UNHCR. But producers ignored the undertaking and, after a short segment on refugees, ambushed her with an arranged reading of a scene from Sex and the City. Other media organisations who tried to get interviews with Davis were told the award-winning humanitarian would speak only about the refugee crisis. Davis was sat at a table with Armytage who was dressed as Carrie Bradshaw in a blonde curly wig and read dialogue from the show. Co-host Natalie Barr was also wearing a wig. While Davis was polite she did look embarrassed and she said: “I don’t know that this is a great idea, frankly” . After the segment aired, Davis took to Twitter to confirm her displeasure, retweeting a fan who said: “That was the worst piece of TV I’ve ever seen. Kristin, you and your charity work is great. Shame Sunrise.” Davis later responded positively to a tweet from Channel Nine’s Lisa Wilkinson inviting her to talk on Sunrise’s rival show next time she was in Australia. The executive producer of Sunrise, Michael Pell, had apologised for the segment on Thursday by saying the crew were all Sex and the City “tragics”. “Our obsession may have gotten the better of us,” Pell said. “We apologise for the bad acting and terrible costumes and we thank Kristin for being such a good sport. She is one of the most gracious stars we’ve ever had on Brekky Central.” Co-host David Koch and Armytage also apologised on air on Friday morning, but it wasn’t enough to repair Armytage’s relationship with the humanitarian organisation. In his apology at the end of the show Koch said that the Sex and the City skit was meant to be a bit of fun but Davis was offended. He said that since the segment had gone to air Australia for UNHCR had asked Armytage not to host and not to attend the lunch. Armytage said she was always willing to host, she supports the work of the organisation and she wishes them well. Davis appeared on Ten’s The Project on Thursday evening, where the hosts joked about the Sunrise wig incident and asked her only one question about Sex and the City at the end of the interview. On Friday afternoon Australia for UNHCR and the Seven Network put out a joint statement. “Kristin Davis is a passionate high profile supporter of UNHCR,” it said. “She has demonstrated this through her tireless commitments globally, as well as her recent trips to Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo where she met Sister Angelique Namaika and saw UNHCR projects supporting refugee women and girls. “She came to Australia to help us launch the ‘I will’ campaign and raise much needed awareness and funds for refugees and displaced people living in shocking conditions. “By joint agreement from Network 7 and Australia for UNHCR, it was decided that today’s ‘In Conversation with Kristin Davis’ lunch at the Ivy Ballroom would be MC’d by Naomi Steer, National Director, Australia for UNHCR, to allow the focus to remain firmly on this important issue.”
